div.p:
I have been horribly ungrateful
and ill-bred - but then I have
been ill and a cripple confined
to my bed - I fell from a ladder
upon which at my time of day
I had no business to mount
& cut and bruised my leg so
that I have been not even al
lowed for some time the use
of my hands as I was compelled
to lie flat - It was while
I was in this condition that I
received your most kind &
valuable present - all the pre-
cautions precautions you took to ensure
its reaching me safely & free
perfectly succeeded and I was
and am much flattered by
your attention and obliged by your
Memorial of Kindness from the
Author - I like the Athenian
Capture very much - and
hope you will keep the copyright
to yourself.

I am particularly obliged
by your intention to introduce
my name by hook or by crook
among your grateful corres
pondents correspondents - and I am sure
that whatever way you do it
will be best and therefore I beg
you to say what you please, of
me and for me -

I should observe however
as to the exact truth of the matter
that I have some little scrap of
interest in copy copyright as I have not
sold that of Helen - but I have given
leave to Bentley to print a stereotype
Edn. & I think that comes pretty
nearly to the same thing - I only
mention this for accuracy's sake
- that you may if you think it
worth while frame your sentence
so as to assert that Miss E has
little or no personal interest
in the matter -

I am so shamefully ignorant as
to my own business concerning
copyright (which was always
managed for me by my father while
he lived) that I have at last resolved
to write to my old publisher poor
Hunter Johnsons nephew to ask
him to inform me how the
matter stands as far as he can
recollect or find out by his papers

The inclosed letter, which I
take the liberty to beg you will
have put with the 2d post for me
is to ask these questions & if I
find that any good comes of them
for
me I shall presume so far upon
your kind interest as to let
you know of it -
Still with disinterested thanks
& pure admiration of your
eloquent exertions for the
literary British Community
and in truth for the whole world
of literature I am
div.closer:
Dear Sir
Yours gratefully
Maria Edgeworth

postscript.p:
Vicarage Town
Mr. Butler, my brother in law,
from whose house I write
was a school fellow of
yours at Reading and
hopes (& so do I) that you
remember him - He is
naturally proud of you
